video.title: Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

I remember my first Yakuza game. Yakuza 4. The 
unique blend of style, likeable characters,

astonishingly brutal violence and that one 
minigame where you choose the prettiest dress

for your paid girlfriend made me go &quot;Ooh!&quot; But as 
time went on with each new Yakuza game I played I

added another word to that statement. &quot;Ooh! 
Yakuza!&quot; &quot;Ooh! Yakuza game!&quot; &quot;Ooh! Another

Yakuza game!&quot; &quot;Ooh boy, another Yakuza game!&quot; 
&quot;OH BOY ANOTHER BLOODY YAKUZA GAME.&quot; &quot;Excuse me,

Yahtz, it&#39;s actually called Like a Dragon now.&quot; 
Oh, so we DON&#39;T play as a good-hearted Yakuza or

ex-Yakuza with ass-kicking fighting skills who 
gets embroiled in a conspiracy while attempting

to protect an innocent woman and ends up in 
a climactic punch up with no shirt on? &quot;Er.

You can dress up like a hula dancer now.&quot; 
Yeah, I was gonna bring that up. Yakuza has

always been tonally schizophrenic but Like 
A Dragon&#39;s deliberate lean into the wacky

humor makes it all the more of a lurch when it 
shows us ultra-gritty violent torture scenes in

which a dude shoots off another dude&#39;s fingers or 
crucifies a dude to a wall and eviscerates him,

and then two seconds later we confront 
the one responsible by whacking him with a

surfboard so he flies into the path of our hula 
dancer party member&#39;s flying buttock strike.

Which I&#39;m sure sounds like it makes for an 
interesting game, but that&#39;s just the established

baseline, and frankly after the breath of fresh 
air that was the first Like A Dragon with its new

turn-based combat system and new protagonist, 
I spent much of my time with Infinite Wealth

waiting in vain for it to differentiate 
itself in any meaningful way. But no,

after ya boy Ichiban Kasuga finds himself down on 
his luck and at the end of his rope once again,

he&#39;s given a hot tip on an innocent woman 
he could defend and shoots off to Hawaii

to get embroiled in a conspiracy doing so. 
And after tearfully parting ways with his

original adventuring party - punch man, hot 
lady and speccy homeless wizard - he lands on

the tarmac and almost immediately befriends a 
new adventuring party consisting of punch man,

hot lady and speccy taxi driver wizard. The punch 
man in question being Kazuma Kiryu of all people,

who tried his level best to finally escape this 
fucking franchise by fleeing to another country

and putting on a bad toupee made of Christmas 
tinsel but apparently it wasn&#39;t enough.

So the turn-based party combat system is 
practically unchanged from the last game,

complete with all the problems I had with it. 
We still get constantly harassed by low-level

random goons far past the point that any XP 
gained from kicking their teeth in scarcely

covers the cost of shoe leather maintenance so 
it&#39;s like I&#39;m making breakfast and the ants on

the kitchen floor keep trying to start shit. And 
during combat everyone constantly shifts position

like awkward people trying to get to a toilet on 
the far side of a wedding reception dance floor

which makes it very annoying when you&#39;re trying to 
heal the whole party and Kiryu decides it&#39;s more

important to scratch his arse on a bicycle stand 
fifty yards away. Also the job system returns,

wherein can be found the afore-discussed hula 
dancer class, but it doesn&#39;t unlock until you&#39;re,

like, four major dungeons into the 
game. I knew it had to exist, though,

&#39;cos half the available shops on the map were all 
like &quot;Oh, this is where you buy weapons for Chefs,

Prostitutes and Supply Teachers, which 
you won&#39;t be able to use for another

five hundred story missions and everything 
costs fifteen thousand bucks anyway.&quot; If I

wanted to be teased this much I&#39;d use the glory 
hole in the toilets at the dementia hospital.

Which goes part of the way to illustrating 
just how glacially paced Like A Dragon:

Infinite Warfare is. The above plot summary 
covers about the first fifteen hours of gameplay,

it&#39;s about three hours before you even get to 
Hawaii, and even that wasn&#39;t much of a sea change,

&#39;cos apparently the entire population of 
Honolulu has taken Japanese lessons. And,

y&#39;know, it&#39;s the same sea. But I put my hands up 
to my own part in this, I made a tactical error.

See, I&#39;m bored of the very samey main plots of 
Yakuza games - defend innocent woman, embroil,

conspiracy, shirts off punch man theme tune 
to the magic roundabout etc etc - when it&#39;s

always the side stuff where the actual fun 
can be found, so I resolved to not worry

about finishing the critical path of Like 
A Dragon: Infinite Wallpaper and do all the

sidequests whenever they pop up. And that was a 
mistake because the optional-optional sidequests,

while occasionally featuring amusing bespoke 
minigames are mostly kinda boring random person

has problem which at some point is resolved by 
beating the snot out of four or five random toughs

who emerge from the background at one point 
like a magic eye picture, lessons are learned

and we part as better, more complete people, 
situations. Turns out the fun side quests are

the nonoptional-optional ones that you&#39;re forced 
into at random points of the critical path.

On that front we have an entire cocking Pokemon 
knockoff - gosh it&#39;s a good time for those at the

moment, apparently, isn&#39;t it - in which we recruit 
and battle small groups of creepy men. Alongside

it but not interacting with it we also have a 
full on Pokemon Snap knockoff in which we must

take pictures of a similar but distinct cadre of 
creepy men - I&#39;m noticing a theme emerging here,

Like A Dragon, someone&#39;s been spending too much 
time on public transport - and then at one point

the plot goes &quot;Okay go stand over there for a 
second,&quot; and when we do that we get kidnapped and

wake up in fucking Animal Crossing. And this was 
the one I was waiting for, the new Hawaiian-themed

version of the business management sim aspect of 
the last game, except now with the cozy crafting

and resource gathering of a Stardew Valley or 
a Bear and Breakfast. Depending on your usual

gaming habits this is the moment where Like 
A Dragon InbilyDimbily may totally lose you,

but it&#39;s OK, just do what it says for a little 
while and eventually it&#39;ll let you ride a dolphin

back to the main plot so you can get embroiled 
some more. But I like a cozy chillout session.

It&#39;s just weird to find one in my game about 
curbstomping crims with flying buttock strikes.

It may be a misstep, frankly. Deciding on the 
maximally efficient positioning for a sofa

lacks the high energy that the last game&#39;s 
business sim somehow managed to pull off,

even when it throws the now requisite cadre of 
creepy men at you for you to deck with a baseball

bat while gathering wood in the morning. It&#39;s 
kinda amazing how the franchise that invented

disco suit bicycle duelling could include such 
a terrible real time combat system. The issue

is that Yakuza games love realistic character 
animation to a degree bordering on obsessive,

and while on the one hand it makes it weirdly 
hypnotic to watch Ichiban ascend a flight

of stairs, the constant easing into and out of 
animations makes it very annoying to line up with

the trees, rocks and human skulls you&#39;re trying 
to baseball bat into submission. In conclusion,

like all Yakuza games Like A Dragon Interminable 
Waffling will blow your mind if it&#39;s the first

one you&#39;ve ever played, but as a veteran, it 
left me disappointed. The whole experience

put me in mind of spending an afternoon 
with a doddering elderly relative. &quot;Hey,

shall we go unlock the job system, 
Like A Dragon?&quot; &quot;Now hold your horses,

let&#39;s make sure everything&#39;s nice and tidy first. 
Ooh, look at all these pictures of creepy men I&#39;ve

taken. What were we talking about?&quot; &quot;Job system, 
Like A Dragon.&quot; &quot;I remember, I remember, I&#39;m not

that far gone. Let&#39;s stop getting distracted. 
Ooh, how long&#39;s this glory hole been here?&quot;
